required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Efficacy and Safety of CD5789 (Trifarotene) 50μg/g Cream Versus Vehicle Cream in Acne Vulgaris
clinical_study.official_title: A Multi-Center, Randomized, Double-Blind, Parallel-Group Vehicle Controlled Study To Compare The Efficacy And Safety Of CD5789 (Trifarotene) 50μg/g Cream Versus Vehicle Cream In Subjects With Acne Vulgaris

brief_summary.textblock: Assessment of the efficacy and safety of CD5789 (trifarotene) 50μg/g cream applied once daily for 12 weeks in subjects with acne vulgaris.

detailed_description.textblock: Clinical Trial for each subject is approximately 14 weeks and are randomized to one of the two treatments for 12 weeks. Subjects must be 9 years of age and older with acne vulgaris.

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.measure: Investigator Global Assessment (IGA) Success Rate at Week 12
primary_outcome.description: Number of subjects who achieved an Investigator Global Assessment (IGA) score of 1 (almost clear) or 0 (Clear) and at least a 2-grade improvement from Baseline to Week 12.

intervention.description: CD5789 (trifarotene) 50µg/g cream applied once daily for 12 weeks.
Placebo cream applied once daily for 12 weeks

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- The subject is a male or female, 9 years of age or older, at Screening visit.
- The Subject has moderate acne at Screening and Baseline.
- The subject is a female of non childbearing potential
- The subject is a female of childbearing potential with a negative pregnancy test and who is strictly abstinent or who agrees to use an effective and approved contraceptive method for the duration of the study and at least 1 month after the last study drug application.
Exclusion Criteria:
- The subject has severe forms of acne (e.g., acne conglobate, acne fulminant) or secondary acne form (e.g.,chloracne, drug-induced acne, etc.).
- The subject has any uncontrolled or serious disease or any medical or surgical condition that may either interfere with the interpretation of the trial results and/or put the subject at significant risk (according to the Investigator's judgment) if the subject takes part to the trial.
- The subject has been exposed to excessive ultraviolet (UV) radiation within one month prior to the Baseline visit or the subject is planning intense UV exposure during the study (i.e., occupational exposure to the sun, sunbathing, tanning salon use, phototherapy, etc.)
- The subject is unwilling to refrain from use of prohibited medication during the clinical trial

category.title: Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

measure.title: Physician Global Assessment Scale Face
measure.description: 0 - Clear (Clear skin with no inflammatory or non-inflammatory lesions.) - Almost Clear (A few scattered comedones and a few small papules.) - Mild (Easily recognizable; less than half the surface is involved. Some comedones and some papules and pustules.) - Moderate (More than half of the surface is involved. Many comedones, papules and pustules. One nodule may be present.) - Severe (Entire surface is involved. Covered with comedones, numerous papules and pustules. Few nodules may be present.)

outcome.title: Investigator Global Assessment (IGA) Success Rate at Week 12
outcome.description: Number of subjects who achieved an Investigator Global Assessment (IGA) score of 1 (almost clear) or 0 (Clear) and at least a 2-grade improvement from Baseline to Week 12.

reported_events.time_frame: Each participant's adverse events were collected starting at the first visit (screening) until the last visit (Week 12).

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: The only disclosure restriction on the PI is that the sponsor can review results communications prior to public release and can embargo communications regarding trial results for a period that is less than or equal to 60 days. The sponsor cannot require changes to the communication and cannot extend the embargo.
